Geometridae insects, also known as geometrid moths or inchworms, use a combination of visual and chemical cues to navigate in low-light or dark environments. 

Visual navigation: 

Many geometrid moths have compound eyes that are highly sensitive to low levels of light. These eyes are designed to pick up even the slightest bit of light, allowing the insect to see its surroundings and navigate through them. 

In addition, some geometrid moths have specialized structures in their eyes called tapetum lucidum, which reflect light back through the retina to enhance the sensitivity of their visual system. This helps them to see even in very low-light conditions. 

Chemical navigation: 

Geometrid moths also rely heavily on chemical cues to navigate in the dark. They use pheromones to locate potential mates, and they can detect the chemicals released by plants to find food sources. 

In some cases, geometrid moths may also use their sense of touch to navigate in the dark. They have specialized sensory structures called sensilla on their antennae and legs that help them to detect changes in their environment and navigate around obstacles. 

Overall, geometrid moths have evolved a range of specialized adaptations that allow them to navigate effectively in low-light or dark environments, ensuring their survival in these challenging habitats.
